title: How do I respond to a court summons? Do I have to respond to the summons thru the court or can I write up my own doc and mail it
question: I have not received any prior notice from this hired attorney. This is an old credit card debt. It was opened in 08/2002 and charged off in 05/ 2006. Last payment was 05/2005. Do I have to go through the courts and pay the court fee's in order to respond to this summons?
answers:
There are companies called "debt buyers" who buy up huge quantities of debts and generally sue on them all. They do not distinguish between debts that are time-barred or otherwise defensible, and count on the fact that consumers won't know how to properly raise the legal issues, and so they will win. That is usually exactly what happens.

If you do your own response you are playing right into their hands. You cannot possibly know the proper way to defend. There are attorneys who specialize in debt collection defense. You should seriously consider consulting one of then - if the suit was filed improperly, it may be extremely defensible, and it may also be that they would have to pay your attorneys' fees and damages, but there is no way to get there on your own.

The National Association of Consumer Advocates is a non-profit consumer advocacy organization. NACA maintains a web site at www.naca.net where it lists geographically consumer law attorneys all over the US. Please look there for someone in your area who specializes in debt collection defense to advise you.
